tit.cmt: クォーテーション削除、カッコ内の単語を小文字に変更

sen.j: 柔術（じゅうじゅつ）は、日本古来の徒手あるいは短い武器による攻防の技法を中心とした武術である。
sen.e: Jujutsu is the name for traditional Japanese martial arts, which are centered on offense & defense techniques with no (or a small) weapon.
Jujutsu is the name for traditional Japanese martial arts, which are centered on offense and defense techniques with no (or a small) weapon.
Jujutsu is the name for traditional Japanese martial arts, which are centered on offense and defense techniques with no (or a small) weapon.

sen.j: 相手を殺傷せずに捕らえたり、身を護ること（護身術）を重視する流儀の多いことは、他国の武術と比較して大きな特徴である。
sen.e: Compared with other countries' martial arts, it is quite characteristic of jujutsu to have many "ryugi" (schools) which emphasize both capturing the opponent without killing (or injuring) it & defense (the art of self-defense).

Compared with other countries' martial arts, it is quite characteristic of jujutsu to have many ryugi (schools) which emphasize both capturing the opponent without killing (or injuring) it and defense (the art of self-defense).
sen.cmt: &→andに修正、クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Compared with other countries' martial arts, it is quite characteristic of jujutsu to have many ryugi (schools) which emphasize both capturing the opponent without killing (or injuring) him or her and defense (the art of self-defense).

sen.j: このような技法は広く研究され、流派が多数存在した。
sen.e: Such techniques were widely sought, and there existed many schools.
Such techniques were widely sought, and there existed many schools.
Such techniques were widely sought, and there existed many schools.

sen.j: 柔・和・和術（やわら）・柔道・体術・胎術（たいじゅつ）・白打・活殺術・挫術・逆手術・腰廻・小具足術・組討・組打・組討術・組打術（くみうち）・鎧組討術・鎧組打術・武者取・取捨術・捕手術・取手・捕縛・手拍・手縛・拳・拳法など、その異称や類似の武術は数多い。
sen.e: There exist many other names of jujutsu & many other martial arts similar to jujutsu, such as "yawara" (the literal meaning is softness, or harmony) or "yawara-jutsu" (literally, the art of harmony), "judo" (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense), "tai-jutsu" (unarmed combat techniques), "hakuda" (a jujutsu-like system that was either of Chinese origin or influenced by Chinese martial arts), "kassatsu-jutsu" (the art of life & death), "hishigi" (joint locking techniques), "gyakute-jutsu" (wrist locking techniques), "koshi no mawari" (sword grappling), "kogusoku-jutsu" (techniques of short sword grappling), "kumiuchi" (grappling) or "kumiuchi-jutsu" (grappling techniques), "yoroi kumiuchi-jutsu" (grappling techniques in armor), "mushadori" (arm constriction), "shusha-jutsu" (techniques of joint-lock throw), "torite-jutsu" (catching hand techniques) or "torite" (catching hand), "hobaku" (binding techniques), "shubaku" (the name of modern martial arts in China), "ken" (fist) or "kenpo" (the bare-hands martial art of Chinese origin, mainly occupied by body-striking techniques).
sen.cmt: ・「体術」、「捕縛」の訳については①を、「白打」については②を、そして「手拍」については③を参照しました。[http://materms.oninohana.com] (①） [http://maxpages.com/hakudaryu/Hakuda_Ryu_Kempo_jutsu] (②） [www.uta.edu/studentorgs/umaa/htmlDocs/history.html] の "China" の項目の第4段落（③）。
sen.e: There exist many other names of jujutsu and many other martial arts similar to jujutsu, such as "yawara" (the literal meaning is softness, or harmony) or "yawara-jutsu" (literally, the art of harmony), "judo" (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense), "tai-jutsu" (unarmed combat techniques), "hakuda" (a jujutsu-like system that was either of Chinese origin or influenced by Chinese martial arts), "kassatsu-jutsu" (the art of life and death), "hishigi" (joint locking techniques), "gyakute-jutsu" (wrist locking techniques), "koshi no mawari" (sword grappling), "kogusoku-jutsu" (techniques of short sword grappling), "kumiuchi" (grappling) or "kumiuchi-jutsu" (grappling techniques), "yoroi kumiuchi-jutsu" (grappling techniques in armor), "mushadori" (arm constriction), "shusha-jutsu" (techniques of joint-lock throw), "torite-jutsu" (catching hand techniques) or "torite" (catching hand), "hobaku" (binding techniques), "shubaku" (the name of modern martial arts in China), "ken" (fist) or "kenpo" (the bare-hands martial art of Chinese origin, mainly occupied by body-striking techniques).

There exist many other names of jujutsu and many other martial arts similar to jujutsu, such as "yawara" (the literal meaning is softness, or harmony) or "yawara-jutsu" (literally, the art of harmony), "judo" (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense), "tai-jutsu" (unarmed combat techniques), "hakuda" (a jujutsu-like system that was either of Chinese origin or influenced by Chinese martial arts), "kassatsu-jutsu" (the art of life and death), "hishigi" (joint locking techniques), "gyakute-jutsu" (wrist locking techniques), "koshi no mawari" (sword grappling), "kogusoku-jutsu" (techniques of short sword grappling), "kumiuchi" (grappling) or "kumiuchi-jutsu" (grappling techniques), "yoroi kumiuchi-jutsu" (grappling techniques in armor), "mushadori" (arm constriction), "shusha-jutsu" (techniques of joint-lock throw), "torite-jutsu" (catching hand techniques) or "torite" (catching hand), "hobaku" (binding techniques), "shubaku" (the name of modern martial arts in China), "ken" (fist) or "kenpo" (the bare-hands martial art of Chinese origin, mainly occupied by body-striking techniques).

sen.j: 柔術の定義については、流派が数多くあり、技法の内容も多種多様であるため、一概には言えないが、例えば講道館の創始者嘉納治五郎は、「無手或は短き武器をもって、無手或は武器を持って居る敵を攻撃し、または防御するの術」である、と柔術を定義した。
sen.e: Having various schools and techniques, jujutsu is difficult to be defined uniformly, but, for example, Jigoro KANO, who was the founder of "Kodokan judo" (the judo form of Kodokan Judo Institute), defined it as the offense & defense techniques using no (or a small) weapon against an armed or unarmed opponent.
sen.cmt: ・ここの「講道館」は後列にいう「講道館柔道」のことと解して訳しています。
sen.e: Having various schools and techniques, jujutsu is difficult to be defined uniformly, but, for example, Jigoro KANO, who was the founder of "Kodokan judo" (the judo form of Kodokan Judo Institute), defined it as the offense and defense techniques using no (or a small) weapon against an armed or unarmed opponent.

Having various schools and techniques, jujutsu is difficult to be defined uniformly, but, for example, Jigoro KANO, who was the founder of "Kodokan judo" (the judo form of Kodokan Judo Institute), defined it as the offense and defense techniques using no (or a small) weapon against an armed or unarmed opponent.

sen.j: 柔道や合気道は、時代が進んでその名が広まるにつれ、これらの名称に「柔術」の語が含まれていない事から、これらが柔術のひとつであるという認識は希薄になり、また、武道としての発展の道へ進んだ。
sen.e: "Judo" (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense) & "aikido" (the traditional Japanese martial art exclusively used for self-defense) both originated from jujutsu, but as times went by and these arts became famous, people's recognition of the origin began to fade away partly because they do not have "jujutsu" in their names, and they developed as the independent martial art.

Judo (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense) and aikido (the traditional Japanese martial art exclusively used for self-defense) both originated from jujutsu, but as times went by and these arts became famous, people's recognition of the origin began to fade away partly because they do not have 'jujutsu' in their names, and they developed as the independent martial art.
sen.cmt: &→andに修正、クォーテーション修正
sen.e: Judo (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense) and aikido (the traditional Japanese martial art exclusively used for self-defense) both originated from jujutsu, but as times went by and these arts became famous, people's recognition of the origin began to fade away partly because they do not have 'jujutsu' in their names, and they developed as the independent martial art.

sen.j: よって、「柔術」というと江戸時代以前から伝わる伝統的な柔術を指す場合が多くなった。
sen.e: Therefore, "jujutsu" has come to mean, in many cases, "koryu jujutsu" (the old-style jujutsu) handed down from before the Edo period.
sen.cmt: ・ここに言う「伝統的な柔術」は、後列に言う「古流柔術」のことであると解して訳しています。
sen.e: Therefore, 'jujutsu' has come to mean, in many cases, "koryu jujutsu" (the old-style jujutsu) handed down from before the Edo period.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: Therefore, 'jujutsu' has come to mean, in many cases, "koryu jujutsu" (the old-style jujutsu) handed down from before the Edo period.

sen.j: また、最近ではメディア (媒体)への露出の機会が多いことなどから、単に「柔術」というとこの日本の柔術ではなく、ブラジリアン柔術（Jiu-jitsu）を指す場合も多い。
sen.e: And nowadays, when we simply say "jujutsu," it often indicates not the Japanese one, but Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, partly because Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu often appears on the media.
sen.cmt: ・「ブラジリアン柔術」のスペルについては[www.ibjjf.org/] の表記に従っています。
sen.e: And nowadays, when we simply say 'jujutsu,' it often indicates not the Japanese one, but Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, partly because Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu often appears on the media.
sen.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: And nowadays, when we simply say 'jujutsu,' it often indicates not the Japanese one, but Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, partly because Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu often appears on the media.

sen.j: また、このブラジリアン柔術の特徴により、柔術＝ブラジリアン柔術＝寝技という認識になっていることも多い。
sen.e: So many people equate jujutsu with Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, and regard its main technique as "newaza" (ground grappling techniques) for the nature of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.
sen.cmt: ・原文の「柔術＝ブラジリアン柔術＝寝技という認識になっている」の部分は、少々意訳して「柔術をブラジリアン柔術と同一視し、その主たる技を寝技とみなしている」としています。
sen.e: So many people equate jujutsu with Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, and regard its main technique as "newaza" (ground grappling techniques) for the nature of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.
So many people equate jujutsu with Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu, and regard its main technique as "newaza" (ground grappling techniques) for the nature of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.

sen.j: その他、国際的に柔術（Ju-jitsu）というと、ヨーロッパ柔術とも呼ばれるJJIF柔術（Ju-jitsu）・IJJF柔術（Jujitsu）を指す場合も多い。
sen.e: Besides, Ju-Jitsu in foreign countries often indicates that of Ju-Jitsu International Federation (JJIF), or that of International Jujitsu Federation (IJJF), and both of them are also called European Ju-Jitsu.
sen.cmt: ・①JJIF、②IJJFのそれぞれのフルスペリングについては以下のホームページを参照しています。[http://www.jjifweb.com/html/welcome.html] (①） [http://www.ijjf.com/] (②）
sen.e: Besides, Ju-Jitsu in foreign countries often indicates that of Ju-Jitsu International Federation (JJIF), or that of International Jujitsu Federation (IJJF), and both of them are also called European Ju-Jitsu.

Besides, Ju-Jitsu in foreign countries often indicates that of Ju-Jitsu International Federation (JJIF), or that of International Jujitsu Federation (IJJF), and both of them are also called European Ju-Jitsu.

sen.j: 合戦のための武芸である組討や、人を捕らえるための捕手などと呼ばれた武技がすでに行われていた。
sen.e: There already existed some martial arts, such as "kumiuchi" (grappling) used for a battle, and "torite" (catching hand) used for capturing a person.
There already existed some martial arts, such as "kumiuchi" (grappling) used for a battle, and "torite" (catching hand) used for capturing a person.
There already existed some martial arts, such as "kumiuchi" (grappling) used for a battle, and "torite" (catching hand) used for capturing a person.

sen.j: 柔術は江戸時代になってからの呼び名である。
sen.e: The name jujutsu began to be used from the Edo period.
sen.cmt: ・原文では文章が途中で切れた形になっていますが、英文でそのようにすると不自然ですので完結した一文としています。
sen.e: The name jujutsu began to be used from the Edo period.
The name jujutsu began to be used from the Edo period.

sen.j: 戦場における組討の技術（弓・鉄砲、槍、刀剣の間合いに続く格闘における技術。敵将の首を取ることも行われた。)
sen.e: The techniques of kumiuchi at a battleground: While making some space, fighters fought against the opponents with an arrow, a harquebus, a spear, or a sword, and then they used these techniques in a physical combat; by that means, they also cut off the head of the opponents' leader.

sen.j: 武士の小太刀、小刀、脇差などでの護身術（小具足術など）
sen.e: The self-defense techniques of the samurai with a dagger, a knife, or a short sword: Kogusoku-jutsu (The techniques of short sword grappling) and others
The self-defense techniques of the samurai with a dagger, a knife, or a short sword: Kogusoku-jutsu (The techniques of short sword grappling) and others

sen.j: 相撲（武士は相撲も組討のための鍛錬方法とした。)
sen.e: Sumo: The samurai used sumo as the training method for kumiuchi.
Sumo: The samurai used sumo as the training method for kumiuchi.

sen.j: 治安維持のための逮捕術（捕手術、捕縛術など）
sen.e: The arresting techniques for the maintenance of the public order: "Torite-jutsu" (Catching hand techniques), "hobaku-jutsu" (binding techniques) and others
The arresting techniques for the maintenance of the public order: "Torite-jutsu" (Catching hand techniques), "hobaku-jutsu" (binding techniques) and others

sen.j: 以上などが柔術の源流である。
sen.e: These were the origin of jujutsu.
sen.cmt: ・前列とは一応別の文章として訳しています。
sen.e: These were the origin of jujutsu.

sen.j: 戦国時代が終わってこれらの技術が発展し、禅の思想や中国の思想や医学などの影響も受けるようになる。
sen.e: After the Sengoku period (the Warring States period), the above-mentioned techniques developed, and they began to be influenced by the philosophy of "Zen" (a sect of Buddhism, which emphasizes focusing one's mind), and by the Chinese philosophy & medical science.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After the Sengoku period (the Warring States period), the above-mentioned techniques developed, and they began to be influenced by the philosophy of "Zen" (a sect of Buddhism, which emphasizes focusing one's mind), and by the Chinese philosophy and medical science.

After the Sengoku period (the Warring States period), the above-mentioned techniques developed, and they began to be influenced by the philosophy of "Zen" (a sect of Buddhism, which emphasizes focusing one's mind), and by the Chinese philosophy and medical science.

sen.j: 江戸時代以降には自らの技術は単なる力技ではないという意味などを込めて、柔術、柔道、和、やわらと称する流派が現れ始める（関口新心流、楊心流、起倒流(良移心当流）など）。
sen.e: From the Edo period, some "ryuha" (schools) of the martial arts began to call their own techniques "jujutsu" (the literal meaning is the art of softness), "judo" (literally, the way of softness), or "yawara" (literally, the softness, or harmony), partly because they wanted to say their techniques were not just forcible ones; the schools were, for example, "Sekiguchi Shin Shin-ryu," "Yoshin-ryu," and "Kito-ryu" (also called "Ryoishinto-ryu").
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処 ・「単なる力技でない」ことが「柔術」その他の名称にどう表れているのか示すため、そういった名称の逐語訳も付しておきました。
sen.e: From the Edo period, some ryuha (schools) of the martial arts began to call their own techniques jujutsu, judo, or yawara, partly because they wanted to say their techniques were not just forcible ones; the schools were, for example, Sekiguchi Shin Shin-ryu, Yoshin-ryu, and Kito-ryu (also called Ryoishinto-ryu).
sen.cmt: クォーテーション・スペース削除、jujutsu, judo, yawaraの補足削除
sen.e: From the Edo period, some ryuha (schools) of the martial arts began to call their own techniques jujutsu, judo, or yawara, partly because they wanted to say their techniques were not just forcible ones; the schools were, for example, Sekiguchi Shin Shin-ryu, Yoshin-ryu, and Kito-ryu (also called Ryoishinto-ryu).

sen.j: 中国文化の影響を受け拳法、白打、手搏などと称する流派も現れた。
sen.e: And other schools, influenced by Chinese martial arts, began to call their own techniques "kenpo" (the bare-hands martial art of Chinese origin, mainly occupied by body-striking techniques), "hakuda" (a jujutsu-like system that was either of Chinese origin or influenced by Chinese martial arts), or "shubaku" (the name of modern martial arts in China).
sen.cmt: ・「中国文化」とありますが、「中国文化」一般ではなく「中国武術」の意味と解されます。
sen.e: And other schools, influenced by Chinese martial arts, began to call their own techniques kenpo, hakuda, or shubaku.
sen.cmt: kenpo, hakuda, shubaku→クォーテーション、補足削除
sen.e: And other schools, influenced by Chinese martial arts, began to call their own techniques kenpo, hakuda, or shubaku.

sen.j: ただしこれらの流派でも読みはやわらであることも多い。
sen.e: But these names read as "yawara" in many cases.

tit.e: Around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate
Around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, Edo period
Around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate, Edo period

sen.j: 武者修行の流行とともに全国的に各流派の交流、試合が盛んになり、素手の乱捕用の技が作られ始めた。
sen.e: As the knight-errantry became popular, exchanges & matches between schools became active, and techniques for "randori" (freestyle practice) done with bare hands began to be devised.
As the knight-errantry became popular, exchanges and matches between schools became active, and techniques for "randori" (freestyle practice) done with bare hands began to be devised.

sen.j: 現在ではどのようなルールで行われていたか不明であるが、真剣勝負の場合以外は当身技は除かれたようである。
sen.e: At present, what kind of rules the techniques had in those days is unclear, but "atemi-waza" (body-striking techniques) seems to have been used only in a game played in earnest.
At present, what kind of rules the techniques had in those days is unclear, but "atemi-waza" (body-striking techniques) seems to have been used only in a game played in earnest.

sen.j: また、乱捕は組討に相当するもの、組討の鍛錬になるものとも見做された。
sen.e: And randori was regarded as a substitute & a training for kumiuchi.
And randori was regarded as a substitute and a training for kumiuchi.
And randori was regarded as a substitute and a training for kumiuchi.

sen.j: これらの乱捕の技術が現在の柔道の乱取と試合の源流である。
sen.e: These techniques of randori are the origin of today's judo's randori & matches.
These techniques of randori are the origin of today's judo's randori and matches.

sen.j: 明治初期に多くの柔術師範が藩指南役等の立場を失ったため、柔術は指導されなくなったように言われているが、実際には全国的に地方の村落などで逆に柔術が流行し、娯楽の一種のように受け入れられ大変広まった。
sen.e: After many jujutsu teachers lost their positions of an instructor at a clan in the early Meiji period, jujutsu is said to have got rare to be taught, but in fact, jujutsu became popular in local villages and other places nationwide, and it was loved like a kind of entertainment.

After many jujutsu teachers lost their positions of an instructor at a clan in the early Meiji period, jujutsu is said to have got rare to be taught, but in fact, jujutsu became popular in local villages and other places nationwide, and it was loved like a kind of entertainment.

sen.j: 特に柔術が盛んだった地方では、一つの村落に幾つもの道場が存在し、集落の若者の大部分が入門していたことが様々な記録に残っている。
sen.e: In local areas where jujutsu was especially popular, several practice halls existed in a single village and most young people there became the pupils, various historical records say.

sen.j: この時期の奉納額が多くの寺社に残っている。
sen.e: Dedication tablets (written about jujutsu exhibition matches) are left in many temples and shrines that held the matches in those days.
sen.cmt: ・原文の「奉納額」は、「柔術の奉納試合について記した額」のことと思われます。（これを補うことで柔術の話とどう関連するのか明らかにしたつもりです）。相撲については神前の奉納試合が古くから行われており、柔術も同様の奉納試合が行われていたものと推測されます。
sen.e: Dedication tablets (written about jujutsu exhibition matches) are left in many temples and shrines that held the matches in those days.

tit.e: Appearance of "Kodokan judo" (the judo form of Kodokan Judo Institute)

sen.j: 天神真楊流と起倒流を源流とする講道館柔道が創始された。
sen.e: Kodokan judo, which originated from "Tenjin Shinyo-ryu" (Tenjin Shinyo school of jujutsu) & "Kito-ryu" (Kito school of jujutsu) was established.
Kodokan judo, which originated from Tenjin Shinyo-ryu (Tenjin Shinyo school of jujutsu) and Kito-ryu (Kito school of jujutsu) was established.
sen.cmt: &→andに修正、クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Kodokan judo, which originated from Tenjin Shinyo-ryu (Tenjin Shinyo school of jujutsu) and Kito-ryu (Kito school of jujutsu) was established.

sen.j: 一般的に、明治時代に全く新しい柔道が現れて、古い柔術と対決して柔術側を打ち負かし、柔術が衰退していったと言う形で語られるが、これはやや不正確である。
sen.e: It is generally said that judo, which was freshly born in the Meiji period, confronted, defeated and drove off the old jujutsu, but this is a little inaccurate.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is generally said that judo, which was freshly born in the Meiji period, confronted, defeated and drove off the old jujutsu, but this is a little inaccurate.
It is generally said that judo, which was freshly born in the Meiji period, confronted, defeated and drove off the old jujutsu, but this is a little inaccurate.

sen.j: 警視庁での採用を決定するための試合に講道館が勝利して警視庁に採用されたことと、学校教育への進出により、講道館柔道が全国的に広まったのである。
sen.e: Kodokan judo spread nationwide firstly because it was formally adopted by the Tokyo Police Department for the victory in the match to decide the school to be adopted, and secondly because it made inroads into the school education.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kodokan judo spread nationwide firstly because it was formally adopted by the Tokyo Police Department for the victory in the match to decide the school to be adopted, and secondly because it made inroads into the school education.

Kodokan judo spread nationwide firstly because it was formally adopted by the Tokyo Police Department for the victory in the match to decide the school to be adopted, and secondly because it made inroads into the school education.

sen.j: 草創期の講道館の人間は天神真楊流などの柔術出身者が多く、柔術側からも講道館柔道は新しい柔術の一流派くらいに考えられていた（講道館の道場開きに多くの柔術関係者が招かれている）。
sen.e: In the early days of Kodokan judo, there were many people who came from jujutsu, including those of Tenjin Shinyo-ryu, and people in jujutsu simply regarded Kodokan judo as a new branch of jujutsu; many people in jujutsu were invited on the opening date of Kodokan Judo Institute.

In the early days of Kodokan judo, there were many people who came from jujutsu, including those of Tenjin Shinyo-ryu, and people in jujutsu simply regarded Kodokan judo as a new branch of jujutsu; many people in jujutsu were invited on the opening date of Kodokan Judo Institute.

sen.j: 明治後期になり、講道館柔道が全国に広まるにつれ、試合を講道館のルールで行う柔術道場が増えた。
sen.e: In the later Meiji period, as Kodokan judo spread nationwide, jujutsu practice halls which held their matches in the rules of Kodokan judo also increased.
In the later Meiji period, as Kodokan judo spread nationwide, jujutsu practice halls which held their matches in the rules of Kodokan judo also increased.

sen.j: 柔術が対決で負けて消滅したというより、柔術が柔道化していったのである。
sen.e: It would be appropriate to say jujutsu evolved into judo rather than to say jujutsu disappeared after being defeated by judo.
It would be appropriate to say jujutsu evolved into judo rather than to say jujutsu disappeared after being defeated by judo.
It would be appropriate to say jujutsu evolved into judo rather than to say jujutsu disappeared after being defeated by judo.

sen.j: 実際、高齢の柔道家で柔術の経験者の人間は未だ存在し、現在は柔道道場であるが、遡ると柔術の道場であった所も存在する。
sen.e: Actually, some aged judoists who experienced jujutsu in the past are still alive today, and there also exist some practice halls of judo whose origin was those of jujutsu.
Actually, some aged judoists who experienced jujutsu in the past are still alive today, and there also exist some practice halls of judo whose origin was those of jujutsu.

sen.j: 逆に、講道館は寝技で不遷流柔術などに何度も負けたため寝技を研究することとなったこともある。
sen.e: And occasionally, people on the side of Kodokan judo learned "newaza" (ground grappling techniques), because Kodokan judo was defeated by "Fusen-ryu jujutsu" (Fusen school of jujutsu) and others several times with newaza.

tit.e: Appearance of "Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu" (Daito school of the self-defense martial art)
Appearance of "Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu" (Daito school of the self-defense martial art)
Appearance of "Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu" (Daito school of the self-defense martial art)

sen.j: 明治後期に登場し当時有名となった柔術流派として武田惣角の大東流合気柔術がある。
sen.e: "Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu," which was a jujutsu school established by Sokaku TAKEDA, appeared and became famous in the later Meiji period.

sen.e: Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu, which was a jujutsu school established by Sokaku TAKEDA, appeared and became famous in the later Meiji period.

sen.j: 武田惣角は道場を持たず、講習会形式で各地の警察署などを廻っていた。
sen.e: Sokaku TAKEDA did not have a practice hall of his own, and went around conducting a workshop of his school at local police stations and others.
Sokaku TAKEDA did not have a practice hall of his own, and went around conducting a workshop of his school at local police stations and others.

sen.j: 講道館柔道には無い技法群を持っていることや武田惣角の卓越した技量が数々の武道家たちに支持され、後にいくつかの分派を生んでもいる。
sen.e: This school had a group of techniques that Kodokan judo did not, and Sokaku's outstanding skills were favored by many martial artists, so this school produced some branch schools afterward.

sen.j: 大東流は合気道の源流のひとつである。
sen.e: Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu is one of the origins of aikido.
Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu is one of the origins of aikido.

tit.e: In the Taisho and Showa periods
In the Taisho and Showa periods
Decline of schools of "koryu jujutsu" (the old-style jujutsu)

sen.j: 一般的に、柔術（古流柔術）は、明治時代に柔道が普及してすぐに衰退したように思われているが、明治時代の項で書かれているように急激なものではなかった。
sen.e: Generally, "koryu jujutsu" is thought to have gone into decline immediately after judo became popular in the Meiji period, but as mentioned above, the decline of koryu jujutsu was not so drastic.
Generally, koryu jujutsu is thought to have gone into decline immediately after judo became popular in the Meiji period, but as mentioned above, the decline of koryu jujutsu was not so drastic.
sen.cmt: クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Generally, koryu jujutsu is thought to have gone into decline immediately after judo became popular in the Meiji period, but as mentioned above, the decline of koryu jujutsu was not so drastic.

sen.j: 実際は地方では戦前まで盛んに行われており、大正前後にはまだ多くの流派で多数の門人を抱え発展していた。
sen.e: Actually, jujutsu was actively practiced in local areas until the time of World War Ⅱ, and around the Taisho period, many schools were still prosperous having their own pupils.
Actually, jujutsu was actively practiced in local areas until the time of World War Ⅱ, and around the Taisho period, many schools were still prosperous having their own pupils.

sen.j: 柔道というと地元の柔術流儀をさす場合も多かった。
sen.e: In those days, judo meant a local school of jujutsu in many cases.
In those days, judo meant a local school of jujutsu in many cases.
In those days, judo meant a local school of jujutsu in many cases.

sen.j: (埼玉県での気楽流、奥山念流、真神道流など)
sen.e: For example, "Kiraku-ryu jujutsu" (Kiraku school of jujutsu) in Saitama Prefecture, "Okuyama Nen-ryu jujutsu" (Okuyama Nen school of jujutsu), and "Shin Shinto-ryu jujutsu" (Shin Shinto school of jujutsu) were called judo.

For example, Kiraku-ryu jujutsu (Kiraku school of jujutsu) in Saitama Prefecture, Okuyama Nen-ryu jujutsu (Okuyama Nen school of jujutsu), and Shin Shinto-ryu jujutsu (Shin Shinto school of jujutsu) were called judo.

sen.e: For example, Kiraku-ryu jujutsu (Kiraku school of jujutsu) in Saitama Prefecture, Okuyama Nen-ryu jujutsu (Okuyama Nen school of jujutsu), and Shin Shinto-ryu jujutsu (Shin Shinto school of jujutsu) were called judo.

sen.j: 古流柔術が更に衰退した原因として、その後の第二次大戦と敗戦の影響により稽古が行われなくなったり、また多くの継承者が戦争で亡くなったことがあげられる。
sen.e: Koryu jujutsu went further into decline firstly because the practice was halted owing to World War Ⅱ and Japan's defeat in the war, and secondly because many jujutsu successors were killed in the war.

sen.j: 現代
sen.e: Today
Today
Today

sen.j: 現在でも複数の流派の伝承が存続している。
sen.e: Even today, plural schools' traditional techniques still exist.
Even today, plural schools' traditional techniques still exist.
Even today, plural schools' traditional techniques still exist.

sen.j: 柔道や空手道等の現代武道だけでなく、各種スポーツ競技の普及により古流柔術は省みられなくなった。
sen.e: Few people take notice of koryu jujutsu, because various other sports' competitions become popular, including the modern martial arts, such as judo and "karate" (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense, whose basic techniques are "uchi" [arm strikes], "tsuki" [thrusts] and "keri" [kicks]).

sen.e: Few people take notice of koryu jujutsu, because various other sports' competitions become popular, including the modern martial arts, such as judo and karate (the traditional Japanese martial art mainly used for self-defense, whose basic techniques are "uchi" [arm strikes], "tsuki" [thrusts] and "keri" [kicks]).

sen.j: また継承者が「危険な古流の技術はもう必要ない世の中になった」とし指導を辞める例もある。
sen.e: And some successors stop teaching the koryu jujutsu, saying the world does not need its dangerous techniques any more.

sen.j: かくして古流柔術はまた更に衰退しているが、一方で徐々に復興していく流派もある。
sen.e: In this way, koryu jujutsu become dinosaurs on the whole, but some schools gradually come back.

sen.e: Since the Meiji period, jujutsu has spread to foreign countries.

sen.j: 講道館が外国へと普及する前に、多くの柔術家が海外へ渡った。
sen.e: Before Kodokan judo became popular in foreign countries, many jujutsu artists went there.

sen.j: 神道六合流、不遷流、関口流、堤宝山流、神道揚心流など多くの流派が海外へ伝わった。
sen.e: So many schools of jujutsu were introduced there, such as "Shinto Rokugo-ryu," "Fusen-ryu," "Sekiguchi-ryu," "Tsutsumi Hozan-ryu," and "Shinto Yoshin-ryu."

tit.j: 現代武道の母体としての柔術
tit.e: Jujutsu as the basis of modern martial arts
Jujutsu as the basis of modern martial arts
Jujutsu as the basis of modern martial arts

sen.j: 柔術から生みだされた武道として、柔道・合気道などがある。
sen.e: Some martial arts, such as judo and aikido, derived from jujutsu.
Some martial arts, such as judo and aikido, derived from jujutsu.

sen.j: 柔道は起倒流・天神真楊流などを元に嘉納治五郎が創始した。
sen.e: Based on some schools of jujutsu, such as "Kito-ryu" & "Tenjin Shinyo-ryu," judo was established by Jigoro KANO.
Based on some schools of jujutsu, such as Kito-ryu and Tenjin Shinyo-ryu, judo was established by Jigoro KANO.
sen.cmt: &→andに修正、クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Based on some schools of jujutsu, such as Kito-ryu and Tenjin Shinyo-ryu, judo was established by Jigoro KANO.

sen.j: 投げ、固めの技法から、当身技や武器術も含む技法を網羅した武道を目指したものが柔道であった (前期柔道として現代柔道と区別する者もいる)。
sen.e: Originally, judo aimed to be the martial art covering the techniques from throwing, grappling, body-striking, to weapon-handling; some call this the pre-modern judo to distinguish it from the modern judo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Originally, judo aimed to be the martial art covering the techniques from throwing, grappling, body-striking, to weapon-handling; some call this the pre-modern judo to distinguish it from the modern judo.

Originally, judo aimed to be the martial art covering the techniques from throwing, grappling, body-striking, to weapon-handling; some call this the pre-modern judo to distinguish it from the modern judo.

sen.j: しかし乱取が競技化したことにより (組み付いた状態での) 投げ技と寝技の乱取稽古に特化し、当身技や対武器の技術は形稽古のみで行われた。
sen.e: However, the style of "randori" (freestyle practice) was incorporated into the competition of judo, and judo became specialized in randori of throwing & ground grappling techniques (in a physical contact), while body-striking & counter-weapon techniques were used only in "kata geiko" (practice of "kata" [pre-arranged forms of offense & defense]).
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処 ・「乱取が競技化した」については前列も参考に、「乱取のスタイルが競技に組み込まれた」と訳しています。
sen.e: However, the style of randori (freestyle practice) was incorporated into the competition of judo, and judo became specialized in randori of throwing and ground grappling techniques (in a physical contact), while body-striking and counter-weapon techniques were used only in kata geiko (practice of "kata" [pre-arranged forms of offense and defense]).

sen.j: やがては形稽古自体もあまり行われないものとなった。
sen.e: In time, kata geiko itself became rare to be done.

tit.e: "Kata" of jujutsu established by Greater Japan Martial Virtue Society
tit.cmt: ・後列から「武徳会」は「大日本武徳会」のことと思われますので、フルネームで訳してあります。
tit.e: "Kata" of jujutsu established by Greater Japan Martial Virtue Society
"Kata" of jujutsu established by Greater Japan Martial Virtue Society

sen.j: 明治39年（1906年）7月京都大日本武徳会本部にて、講道館の嘉納治五郎委員長と揚心古流の戸塚英美委員、四天流の星野九門委員、他17名の委員補（双水執流組討腰之廻第十四代青柳喜平、不遷流柔術四代田邊又右衞門など）柔術10流・師範20名で構成される「日本武徳会柔術形制定委員会」により1週間で制定された。
sen.e: In July 1906, at the headquarters of Greater Japan Martial Virtue Society in Kyoto, kata of jujutsu was established in a week by "the committee of Greater Japan Virtue Society for establishing kata of jujutsu" which consisted of 20 masters from 10 jujutsu schools, that is, the chairman Jigoro KANO from Kodokan judo, the committee member Hideyoshi TOTSUKA from "Yoshin Ko-ryu" (Yoshin Ko school of jujutsu), the committee member Kumon HOSHINO from "Shiten-ryu" (Shiten school of jujutsu), and other 17 assistant committee members, including Kihei AOYAGI (the 14th head of "Sosuishi-ryu kumiuchi koshi no mawari" [Sosuishi school of grappling with swords]) and Mataemon TANABE (the fourth head of "Fusen-ryu jujutsu" [Fusen school of jujutsu]).
sen.cmt: ・「大日本武徳会」の訳（①）、「双水執流組討腰之廻」の訳（②）については以下のホームページを参照しました。[http://www.dnbk.org/history.cfm] の第4段落（①） [http://www.sousuishiryu.jp/seirenkan/index.html] (②。ただし日本語のサイト。）
sen.e: In July 1906, at the headquarters of Greater Japan Martial Virtue Society in Kyoto, kata of jujutsu was established in a week by 'the committee of Greater Japan Virtue Society for establishing kata of jujutsu' which consisted of 20 masters from 10 jujutsu schools, that is, the chairman Jigoro KANO from Kodokan judo, the committee member Hideyoshi TOTSUKA from Yoshin Ko-ryu (Yoshin Ko school of jujutsu), the committee member Kumon HOSHINO from Shiten-ryu (Shiten school of jujutsu), and other 17 assistant committee members, including Kihei AOYAGI (the 14th head of Sosuishi-ryu kumiuchi koshi no mawari [Sosuishi school of grappling with swords]) and Mataemon TANABE (the fourth head of Fusen-ryu jujutsu).

sen.j: 講道館柔道を含む全柔術流派を統合する形であった（月刊「武道」 2006年7月号に経緯が掲載される）。
sen.e: All jujutsu-related schools' kata, including Kodokan judo's, was integrated; the integration process was carried on the July 2006 issue of the monthly magazine "The Martial Arts."

sen.j: 講道館柔道形の一部、極の形となった.
sen.e: This kata is the origin of a part of today's Kodokan judo's kata, called "Kime no Kata" (Forms of Decision).

sen.j: 合気道は大東流合気柔術・起倒流・柳生心眼流 ・新陰流などを修めた植芝盛平が始祖である。
sen.e: Aikido was established by Morihei UESHIBA, who mastered "Daito-ryu Aiki jujutsu" (Daito school of the self-defense martial art), and other jujutsu schools such as "Kito-ryu," "Yagyu Shingan-ryu," "Shinkage-ryu."

sen.j: 彼の、大東流合気柔術を骨子に創始した武術「武産合気 (植芝流)」が一般に広く普及（植芝は普及には否定的だったともいわれるが）した現代武道である。
sen.e: His martial art called "Takemusu Aiki (Ueshiba school)," whose core techniques originated from Daito-ryu Aiki-jujutsu, spread to the public - though Ueshiba himself is said to have been unwilling to spread it - and evolved into the modern martial art called aikido.

sen.j: 柔道とは異なり、対武器の技法と腕に対する関節技や投げを中心とした武道である。
sen.e: Different from judo, aikido is the martial art that centers on the techniques of counter-weapon, arm joint locking, and throwing.

sen.j: さらに、富木謙治が合気道に起倒流の要素を加え、乱取りを導入した独自の合気道（日本合気道協会とも呼ばれる）を編み出した。
sen.e: In addition, Kenji TOMIKI added a factor of Kito-ryu jujutsu to aikido, and devised the unique aikido in which "randori" (freestyle practice) was introduced; he was the founder of the Japan Aikido Association.

sen.j: 幾つかの空手道や拳法の流派が柔術の影響を受けて創始されている。
sen.e: Some schools of karate and kenpo were established under the influence of jujutsu.

tit.e: "Wado-ryu karate" (Wado school of karate) & "Wado-ryu jujutsu kenpo" (Wado school of kenpo mixed with jujutsu)
tit.cmt: ・原文の表記からすると、「和道流空手」の別名が「柔術拳法」（＝和道流柔術拳法）であるかに見えますが、両者は別の武術です（後列参照）。それゆえ両者を "&" でつないでいます。

sen.j: 流祖大塚博紀（和道流空手道開祖）は、自身が学んだ神道揚心流と為我流をもとに和道流柔術拳法を編み出した（ただし、和道流柔術拳法は日本古武道協会に柔術流派として加盟していることから、現代武道ではなく古武道である）。
sen.e: Hironori OTSUKA, the founder of Wado-ryu karate, also founded Wado-ryu jujutsu kenpo, based on "Shinto Yoshin-ryu" (Shinto Yoshin school of jujutsu) & "Iga-ryu" (Iga school of jujutsu) which he studied; however, Wado-ryu jujutsu kenpo joined Japanese Classical Martial Arts Association as a school of jujutsu, so it is classified not as the modern martial art, but as the classical one.

tit.e: "Nippon Kempo" (A combat sport based on traditional Japanese martial arts)

sen.j: 直接柔術と関連がないが、柔道で廃れていった当身技の稽古のために生まれたのが日本拳法である。
sen.e: Though not directly related to jujutsu, Nippon Kempo was established for the training of body-striking techniques, which went out of use in judo.

sen.j: 澤山宗海は柔道をもとに（空手道やボクシングも参考にした）、当身と当身から投げ技への変化の技法を専門化した武道として編み出した。
sen.e: Referring to judo, karate and boxing, Muneumi SAWAYAMA devised his Nippon Kempo as the martial art that specialized in body-striking techniques & shifting techniques from body-striking to throwing.

sen.j: 近年のCQCを重視する各国の軍用格闘技に柔術の技が採り入れられていることもある(サンボ等)。
sen.e: In some countries where close quarters combat (CQC) has been stressed on recently, the techniques of jujutsu are introduced into their own military combat sports, such as Sambo.

sen.j: ただし、これは柔術に限らず伝統武術に共通する欠点であるが、習熟に時間がかかる割りに現代では非実戦的な技も多い。
sen.e: However, jujutsu has its drawbacks that much time is needed to master and that many techniques impractical today are included, which are shared with other traditional Japanese martial arts.

sen.j: この点により、伝統流派自体の採用ではなく、一部の技の採用や、各国で独自に近代化した柔術技法などが採用されている。
sen.e: Therefore, those countries adopt not the traditional school as a whole, but some of its techniques partially, and they modernize the jujutsu techniques by themselves.

sen.j: 柔術はおおむね、江戸時代までに興された徒手武術をさす。
sen.e: Roughly speaking, jujutsu means the unarmed martial arts established before the Edo period.

sen.j: 武術としての柔術には、現代柔道、合気道、ブラジリアン柔術等は含まれないが、より明確に分けるために「古流柔術」と呼ぶ事もある（下に記す）。
sen.e: Jujutsu as the martial art does not include the modern judo, aikido, Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and the like, so it is sometimes called "koryu jujutsu" (the old-style jujutsu, mentioned below) to make a clear distinction between itself and these martial arts.

sen.j: また、上記のものは柔術の流れを汲むため、広義では柔術に含まれる。
sen.e: But in a broad sense, jujutsu includes the above-mentioned martial arts, because they also descended from jujutsu.

tit.j: 「柔術」が意味するところの変遷
tit.e: How the meaning of "jujutsu" has changed
How the meaning of 'jujutsu' has changed
tit.cmt: シングルクォーテーションに変更
tit.e: How the meaning of 'jujutsu' has changed

sen.j: 本来、「柔術」は日本における徒手武術全般の総称であるが、その流れを汲む現代柔道、合気道、ブラジルで発展したブラジリアン柔術、ヨーロッパで発展したJJIF柔術・IJJF柔術等も「柔術」に含まれる場合がある。
sen.e: Originally, "jujutsu" is used as the general term for the Japanese unarmed martial arts, but occasionally, "jujutsu" include not only its Japanese descendants (the modern judo & aikido) but also its descendants abroad (Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu developed in Brazil, JJIF Ju-jitsu and IJJF Jujitsu [the latter two were developed in Europe]).

Originally, 'jujutsu' is used as the general term for the Japanese unarmed martial arts, but occasionally, 'jujutsu' includes not only its Japanese descendants (the modern judo and aikido) but also its descendants abroad (Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu developed in Brazil, JJIF Ju-jitsu and IJJF Jujitsu [the latter two were developed in Europe]).
sen.cmt: include→includes、＆→andに修正、シングルクォーテーションに変更
sen.e: Originally, 'jujutsu' is used as the general term for the Japanese unarmed martial arts, but occasionally, 'jujutsu' includes not only its Japanese descendants (the modern judo and aikido) but also its descendants abroad (Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu developed in Brazil, JJIF Ju-jitsu and IJJF Jujitsu [the latter two were developed in Europe]).

sen.j: 柔道 (特に現代柔道)、合気道が世に出、全国に普及して以降、これらと区別するため、日本古来の柔術を「古流柔術」という表現を用いて区別するようになった。
sen.e: From when judo (especially, the modern judo) & aikido emerged and became popular nationwide, the jujutsu handed down from its origin began to be called "koryu jujutsu" (the old-style jujutsu) to make a distinction between itself and the two.

From when judo (especially, the modern judo) and aikido emerged and became popular nationwide, the jujutsu handed down from its origin began to be called 'koryu jujutsu' to make a distinction between itself and the two.

Why jujutsu has become to have such a tendency to exclude atemi-waza is examined below.
Why jujutsu has become to have such a tendency to exclude atemi-waza is examined below.

sen.j: 柔術の流れを汲む柔道の試合に当身技がなく、幕末あたりから各地で行われた他流試合や乱捕稽古も当身技を禁じていた場合が多いこと（現代柔道では多くの形が演武用、セレモニー用となっている傾向がある。)
sen.e: Firstly, the jujutsu descendant judo has no atemi-waza in its match, and jujutsu itself often forbade atemi-waza in "taryu ziai" (a contest between representatives of different schools) and in "randori" (freestyle practice), which both began to be held in many places from around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate; in today's judo's atemi-waza, many "kata" (pre-arranged forms of offense & defense) tend to become an art for a show or for a ceremonial performance.
sen.cmt: ・前列を受け、英訳では原文3行目の「多いこと」の後に「が第一にあげられる。」と補っています。
sen.e: Firstly, the jujutsu descendant judo has no atemi-waza in its match, and jujutsu itself often forbade atemi-waza in "taryu jiai" (a contest between representatives of different schools) and in randori, which both began to be held in many places from around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate; in today's judo's atemi-waza, many "kata" tend to become an art for a show or for a ceremonial performance.
sen.cmt: "taryu ziai"→"taryu jiai"に修正、"randori"→補足・クォーテーション削除、スペース消去、"kata"の補足削除
sen.e: Firstly, the jujutsu descendant judo has no atemi-waza in its match, and jujutsu itself often forbade atemi-waza in "taryu jiai" (a contest between representatives of different schools) and in randori, which both began to be held in many places from around the last days of the Tokugawa shogunate; in today's judo's atemi-waza, many "kata" tend to become an art for a show or for a ceremonial performance.

sen.j: 江戸時代は捕縛術としてそのような技術を中心に据えているような印象を与える流派も多く、かつそれは古流柔術全体の特徴でもある。
sen.e: Secondly, many schools in the Edo period seem to have centered on "hobaku-jutsu" (binding techniques), and this characteristic applies to the whole koryu jujutsu.
sen.cmt: ・上と同様、文末に「ことが第二にあげられる。」と補っています。
sen.e: Secondly, many schools in the Edo period seem to have centered on hobaku-jutsu, and this characteristic applies to the whole koryu jujutsu.
sen.cmt: "hobaku-jutsu"→既出のため補足削除、クォーテーション削除
sen.e: Secondly, many schools in the Edo period seem to have centered on hobaku-jutsu, and this characteristic applies to the whole koryu jujutsu.

sen.j: ブラジリアン柔術の影響はどうか。
sen.e: How about the influence of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu ?
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: How about the influence of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu ?
How about the influence of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu ?

sen.j: その選手は総合格闘技の試合で当身技も使う。
sen.e: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu players use atemi-waza in the match of Mixed Martial Arts.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu players use atemi-waza in the match of Mixed Martial Arts.
Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu players use atemi-waza in the match of Mixed Martial Arts.

sen.j: 他方、ブラジリアン柔術競技では当身技が禁じられている。
sen.e: On the other hand, atemi-waza is forbidden in the Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu competition itself.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, atemi-waza is forbidden in the Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu competition itself.
On the other hand, atemi-waza is forbidden in the Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu competition itself.

sen.j: このように両面があり、抑止要因になったか原因になったか、どちらかは確認されていない。
sen.e: Therefore, it is unclear whether the tendency was deterred or encouraged by Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, it is unclear whether the tendency was deterred or encouraged by Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.
Therefore, it is unclear whether the tendency was deterred or encouraged by Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu.

sen.j: しかし、柔術には嘉納治五郎が柔術を『徒手もしくは小型の武器を持つ武術』と定義したように、その程度しか共通理念はない。
sen.e: However, jujutsu is the martial arts with no (or a small) weapon, as Jigoro KANO defined, and this definition describes the minimum common factor of all jujutsu-related martial arts.
However, jujutsu is a martial art with no (or a small) weapon, as Jigoro KANO defined, and this definition describes the minimum common factor of all jujutsu-related martial arts.
sen.cmt: the martial arts→a martial artとしました。
sen.e: However, jujutsu is a martial art with no (or a small) weapon, as Jigoro KANO defined, and this definition describes the minimum common factor of all jujutsu-related martial arts.

sen.j: したがって、当身技を排除する要素はない。
sen.e: Therefore, atemi-waza is not excluded from jujutsu.
Therefore, atemi-waza is not excluded from jujutsu.
Therefore, atemi-waza is not excluded from jujutsu.

sen.j: 大半の流派で小脇差や鉄扇や十手等を使った当身技や、その他隠し武器術を伝えている。
sen.e: Atcually, most schools of jujutsu have handed down various techniques, such as the atemi-waza which uses a very short sword, an iron fan, or a short truncheon with hook, and the techniques handling secret or disguised weapons.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Atcually, most schools of jujutsu have handed down various techniques, such as the atemi-waza which uses a very short sword, an iron fan, or a short truncheon with hook, and the techniques handling secret or disguised weapons.

sen.j: 素手での当身技法も深く修練する体系になっている流派もある。
sen.e: Some schools of jujutsu discipline their members strictly and systematically also about bare hands' atemi-waza.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Some schools of jujutsu have a system in which their members also train intensively bare hands' atemi-waza.
sen.cmt: 「も深く修練する体系」の部分を修正しました。
sen.e: Some schools of jujutsu have a system in which their members also train intensively bare hands' atemi-waza.
